claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination broadens tumor antigen display, increasing the represented proteins in both the immunopeptidome and the MHC-I peptidome.

evidence.quote: | Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination |
| Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape |
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: These summary values do not specify tumor-model variability, and some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination induces a type I interferon response in tumors, and type I interferon signaling is required for the sensitization benefit.

evidence.quote: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
| Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors |
- Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: The report summarizes the mechanism at a high level; mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination increases PD-L1 pathway activity in tumor tissue, providing a rationale for combining intratumoral vaccination with anti-PD-L1 checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: | PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable |
PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.

claims.caveat: An increase in PD-L1 expression does not by itself guarantee clinical benefit, and translation from mouse tumor settings to diverse human tumors is uncertain.

claims.claim: Combination treatment with intratumoral mRNA vaccination and anti-PD-L1 is associated with increased intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density and improved tumor control in mice.

evidence.quote: - Preclinical arm: multiple murine tumor models with intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations.
| Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change | 1.8x | 1.0x | Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy |
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: The magnitude and consistency of these effects may vary by model system, and mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.

claims.claim: In a retrospective metastatic patient cohort treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors, prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status was associated with improved survival.

evidence.quote: - Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.
| Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |
- The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.caveat: Because the human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized with variable vaccination timing and heterogeneous tumor types, the observed association cannot be interpreted as definitive causation.
